newsitem.title: USA: Toyota seeks to block to Republic acquisition.
newsitem.headline: Toyota seeks to block to Republic acquisition.

text.p: Toyota Motor Corp.'s U.S. unit, Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc., on Thursday filed a petition with California authorities seeking to block Republic Industries Inc.'s acquisition of a Lexus car dealership.

In a statement, Toyota said it is withholding its consent for transfering Fremont, Calif.-based Anderson Lexus "because of Republic's continuing refusal to accept or abide by Toyota's multiple dealer ownership policies."
The petition was filed with the California New Motor Vehicle Board.

Republic, led by Florida billionaire Wayne Huizenga, has grown into the nation's largest car dealership in just six months of aggressive acquisitions this year. Republic, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., owns 150 new car retailers and operates a chain of used car dealerships called AutoNation.
Toyota said its policies are designed to protect the public, other dealers and Toyota against the dangers of a rapid concentration of auto dealers under single ownership.
In April, Toyota became the first major automaker to try to stop Republic from acquiring dealerships when it sought to block Republic's purchase of Joe Myers Toyota in Houston.
American Honda Motor Co., the U.S. unit of Honda Motor Co. Ltd., soon followed Toyota's lead by suing Republic in Texas.
Republic spokesman Jim Donahue said Toyota's new petition appears to be the same as past claims and added the company will pursue the Anderson acquisition as well as others in the future.
He said Republic believes the Toyota policy contradicts state franchise law and contract law.
"At the same time, we continue to discuss the situation with Toyota behind the scenes, and those discussions will go on," said Donahue. "We hope for an early and clean coming to terms."
Republic's stock fell 37.5 cents to $24.625 in consolidated trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
